newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-IRWIN RUNS AWAY FROM FIELD AT PGA SENIORS' CHAMPIONSHIP.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-IRWIN RUNS AWAY FROM FIELD AT PGA SENIORS' CHAMPIONSHIP.

text.p: Defending champion Hale Irwin fired a 7-under-par 65 Friday to open a seven-stroke lead midway through the $1.2 million PGA Seniors' Championship -- the second major event of the year for golf's elder statesmen.

Irwin took the lead from a faltering John Bland with four consecutive birdies on the front nine. Through 36 holes Irwin was at 10-under-par 134, seven shots better than Bob Charles and eight ahead of Gibby Gilbert.

"Don't think this is a common occurrence," said Irwin, who came within two shots of the course record. "I had a remarkable day and the rest of the field didn't. I'll try to approach the next two days like I'm even with everyone else."
Former champion Jack Nicklaus carded an even-par 72 and was tied for fourth with John Morgan, Gil Morgan and Larry Gilbert at 1-under 143.
Bland, who held a two-stroke overnight lead, suffered three double-bogeys, including back-to-back doubles at 16 and 17 to fall nine shots behind Irwin at even-par 144.
"I pulled my second shot on 16 and landed in someone else's pitch mark and couldn't manoeuvre it onto the green and then three-putted," Bland said.
"On 17, I put my tee shot into the left-hand bunker and the ball was plugged. I then blew it out and into the water."

Irwin was two shots back at the start of the day, but caught fire at the par-4 fourth hole, where he sank a 15-foot birdie putt. He hit a 5-iron within 10 feet to set up another birdie at number five, then landed a sand wedge six feet from the cup for his third bird in a row.

Irwin rolled in a 12-foot birdie to make it four straight at number seven, dropping him to 7-under. He made his only mistake at the ninth hole, hitting it over the green and settling for his second bogey of the tournament.
The 51-year-old Irwin didn't need much time to recover, draining a seven-foot birdie putt at number 10.

He moved to 9-under with a spectacular eagle on the par-4 13th hole, holing a pitching wedge from 155 yards out. The two-time U.S. Open champion put an exclamation point on his round with a four-foot birdie on 18.
"I'll stay focused on the task at hand," Irwin said.

"I'll be aggressive when I have to and back off at times. That's the lesson I learned last year," said Irwin, who can become the first player to repeat as champion in this event since the Senior Tour was started in 1980.
